fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and L^\bullet a complex of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that L^\bullet is strictly perfect if it is bounded and each L^i is a direct summand of a locally free \mathscr {O}_X-module of finite rank.
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and L^\bullet a complex of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that L^\bullet is perfect if it is locally quasi-isomorphic to a strictly perfect complex.

If (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a locally ringed space, then a complex L^\bullet of \mathscr {O}_X-modules is strictly perfect if and only if it is bounded and such that each L^i is locally free of finite rank.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is locally ringed, any direct summand of a locally free \mathscr {O}_X-module of finite rank is itself locally free of finite rank ([Stacks:0BCI])

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a locally ringed space, then a complex L^\bullet of \mathscr {O}_X-modules is perfect if and only if it is locally quasi-isomorphic to a bounded complex of locally free modules of finite rank.

L^\bullet is perfect if and only if, for all x\in X, there exists some open neighbourhood U_x of x and some bounded complex L_{U_x}^\bullet of locally free \mathscr {O}_{U_x}-modules of finite rank such that L_{U_x}^\bullet \simeq L^\bullet |_{U_x}.

It turns out that, even if this is all you know, you can prove a surprising amount of non-trivial facts about complex geometry without any algebraic assumptions like "Kähler" or "projective" (i.e. without appealing to GAGA). In particular, we can develop a working theory of coherent analytic sheaves without requiring a preliminary course in algebraic geometry.

fr:p.fr:strong: The purpose of these notes is to explore this approach, and to organise some of its history and exposition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We have already convinced ourselves that sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules (for simplicity, we often just say sheaves) on a ringed space (X,\mathscr {O}_X) are interesting, so now let's consider how we can study them.

One of our main examples of sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules is that of vector bundles (or, really, locally free sheaves). These are particularly nice because they are of finite rank, and, as is often the case in any sort of linear algebra, when things are of "finite dimension" their study becomes less finicky. So a first definition that we could consider is something that requires the existence of "finite bases". Since we're working with sheaves, we don't want to impose some global condition, so it makes sense to ask for our sheaves to be "locally finite dimensional". Formalising this gives the notion of sheaves of finite type. But we immediately run into a problem: this is quite a strong condition to impose, and the sheaves of finite type carve out such a small subcategory of the category of arbitrary sheaves that they do not form an abelian category; kernels and cokernels of morphisms between sheaves of finite type are not necessarily themselves of finite type.

but then we notice an asymmetry, in that this is good for surjections but not yet injections; to fix this it suffices to pass to finite presentation (which is an obvious specific case of quasi-coherent, but one that actually behaves much better for arbitrary locally ringed spaces)

finally, there's a rather slick way of ensuring finite presentation (but a priori strictly stronger) by just saying "finite type" twice, which is the definition of coherent, and this turns out to be equivalent to finite presentation if the structure sheaf itself is coherent; another definition of coherent is "any subsheaf of finite type is of finite presentation", i.e. we find a way to ensure the converse of finite-type=>finite-presentation
coherent is GREAT because it lets us to stalk-to-neighbourhood arguments! this is super useful!

another great thing about coherent is that we always get an abelian category, whereas that's really not clear (or even necessarily true) for the other weaker finiteness conditions; the bad thing is that we lose closure under pullbacks... we would get this back if the structure sheaf were coherent, but that's not always the case! (give the example of smooth functions)

the fact that the holomorphic structure sheaf is coherent is a BIG theorem, because it's often not even Noetherian (e.g. for Stein)! and when the structure sheaf is coherent, we get lots of nice things, e.g. coherence is then preserved under pullbacks

in the algebraic case, especially in the case of a locally Noetherian scheme, all these properties get a bit mixed together ([Stacks:01XZ]) and it can be hard to realise that they're all a priori distinct; you really need non-Noetherian to see the difference (see e.g. MSE:a/1450934)

not going to mention pseudo-coherence really, but note that it's just the natural continuation of finite type, finite presentation, ... ([Stacks:064N])... it's particularly important for when \mathscr {O}_X is not coherent (over itself)

Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that \mathscr {F} is of finite type (or, in some references, finitely generated) if it is locally generated by finitely many sections: if every point x\in X admits a neighbourhood U_x such that there exists an exact sequence (i.e. a surjection) \mathscr {O}_X^{\oplus r_{U_x}} \twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}|_{U_x} \to 0 for some r_{U_x}\in \mathbb {N}.

Any global section \sigma \in \Gamma (X,\mathscr {F}) induces a morphism \mathscr {O}_X\to \mathscr {F} by multiplication of (local) sections: f\mapsto sf. In fact, this induces a bijection, where the inverse is given by associating to any morphism \varphi \colon \mathscr {O}_X\to \mathscr {F} the section \sigma =\varphi (1). We say that \mathscr {F} is generated by sections if there exists a set \{s_i\in \Gamma (X,\mathscr {F})\}_{i\in I} such that the morphism \oplus _{i\in I}s_i\colon \oplus _{i\in I}\mathscr {O}_X\to \mathscr {F} is surjective; if I is finite then we say that \mathscr {F} is finitely generated by sections. By the above bijection, being finitely generated by sections is equivalent simply asking for there to exist a surjection \mathscr {O}_X^{\oplus r}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F} for some r\in \mathbb {N}.

So, being locally generated by finitely many sections means that, for all x\in X, there exists some open neighbourhood U_x of x, some r_x\in \mathbb {N}, and some surjection \mathscr {O}_{U_x}^{\oplus r_x}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}|_{U_x}.

fr:title.text: Properties of sheaves of finite type

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of sheaves of finite type

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Being of finite type is the weakest of the "standard" finiteness notions, but it already has a lot of nice properties. For example, it is closed under pullbacks ([Stacks:01B6]) and extensions ([Stacks:01B7]), and it ensures that the support of the sheaf is closed ([Stacks:01BA]). This last fact comes from maybe the most useful property of being of finite type:
373#258unstable-258.xmlLemma#257
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \varphi \colon \mathscr {F}\to \mathscr {G} a morphism of sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. Assume that there exists x\in X such that \varphi _x\colon \mathscr {F}_x\to \mathscr {G}_x is surjective. If \mathscr {F} is of finite type, then there exists an open neighbourhood U_x of x such that \varphi |_{U_x}\colon \mathscr {F}|_{U_x}\to \mathscr {G}|_{U_x} is surjective.
374#259unstable-259.xmlProof#258 This is [Stacks:01B8].
Being able to turn facts about behaviour at a point into facts about behaviour on an open subset is something that is incredibly useful in the context of holomorphic geometry, since knowing the behaviour of a holomorphic function on an open neighbourhood often tells you something about its global behaviour (as demonstrated by e.g. the identity theorem). So the notion of sheaves of finite type seems like it will be useful, but it is unfortunately not sufficiently well behaved. For example, with sheaves of finite type we can only extend surjectivity from points to neighbourhoods, not injectivity.

Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that \mathscr {F} is of finite presentation if it is locally the cokernel of a morphism of finite-rank free sheaves: if every point x\in X admits a neighbourhood U_x such that there exists an exact sequence \mathscr {O}_{U_x}^{\oplus s_{U_x}} \to \mathscr {O}_{U_x}^{\oplus r_{U_x}} \twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}|_{U_x} \to 0 for some r_{U_x},s_{U_x}\in \mathbb {N}. We call this exact sequence a (finite) presentation of \mathscr {F}|_{U_x}.

fr:title.text: Properties of sheaves of finite presentation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of sheaves of finite presentation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
By definition, finite presentation implies finite type, and, since pullbacks are right-exact and commute with direct sums, we see that the property of being of finite presentation is also closed under pullbacks ([Stacks:01BQ]) and extensions (TO-DO: citation? maybe it follows from [Stacks:0519]?). However, we are now slightly closer to having an abelian category, in that we are slightly closer to having two-out-of-three:
378#262unstable-262.xmlLemma#261
Let 0 \to \mathscr {H} \hookrightarrow \mathscr {G} \twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F} \to 0 be an exact sequence of sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules, with \mathscr {G} and \mathscr {F} assumed to be of finite type. If \mathscr {F} is further of finite presentation, then \mathscr {H} is of finite type.
379#263unstable-263.xmlProof#262 This is [Stacks:01BP].
In other words, it's not true that the kernel of a surjection of sheaves of finite type is itself of finite type, but it is true if the sheaves are of finite presentation (in fact, the lemma above is stronger: we only require the codomain to be of finite presentation).

Having another part of two-out-of-three also gives us another point-to-neighbourhood lemma:
380#264unstable-264.xmlLemma#261
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} an \mathscr {O}_X-module. Assume there exists x\in X such that \mathscr {F}_x\cong \mathscr {O}_{X,x}^{\oplus r} for some r\in \mathbb {N}. If \mathscr {F} is of finite presentation, then there exists an open neighbourhood U_x of x such that \mathscr {F}|_{U_x}\cong \mathscr {O}_{U_x}^{\oplus r}.
381#265unstable-265.xmlProof#264 This is [Stacks:0B8J].

fr:title.text: Motivation for a definition of coherence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Motivation for a definition of coherence

fr:strong.fr:em: TO-DO: we saw above that if things are of finite type, then if they are also of finite presentation then stuff starts to work out well... so can we come up with a condition that ensures that subsheaves of finite type are of finite presentation?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that \mathscr {F} is coherent if the following condition holds:
385#268unstable-268.xmlCondition#267
Any subsheaf \mathscr {G}\subseteq \mathscr {F} of finite type is further of finite presentation.
386#269unstable-269.xmlCaveat#267
This condition on subsheaves has to include \mathscr {F} itself, i.e. \mathscr {F} must be of finite type.

Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. We say that \mathscr {F} is coherent if it is of finite type and further satisfies the condition that locally the kernel of any morphism from a finite-rank free sheaf is of finite type: for every morphism of the form \varphi \colon \mathscr {O}_U^{\oplus r}\to \mathscr {F}|_{U} for r\in \mathbb {N} and U\subseteq X open, the kernel \operatorname {Ker}\varphi is of finite type.
Note that we impose the constraint on the kernel of arbitrary maps from a finite-rank free sheaf, not just on surjections.

fr:title.text: The two definitions of coherence agree

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The two definitions of coherence agree

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
The two definitions of coherence —
\mathscr {F} is of finite type, and all its subsheaves of finite type are of finite presentation
\mathscr {F} is of finite type, and the kernel of any morphism from a finite free sheaf is of finite type
— are equivalent.

By definition, coherent sheaves are also of finite type, but since we are trying to build a hierarchy of finiteness conditions we should show that coherent sheaves are also of finite presentation. Then we will have that [coherent \implies finite presentation \implies finite type].
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. If \mathscr {F} is coherent, then it is also of finite presentation.

This is [Stacks:01BW]. The idea of the (short) proof is to use that \mathscr {F} is of finite type to build a surjection from a finite-rank free sheaf, and then the fact that the kernel of this surjection is also, by the definition of coherence, of finite type; this gives a finite presentation.

fr:title.text: Finiteness conditions on subsheaves of coherent sheaves

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finiteness conditions on subsheaves of coherent sheaves

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Now, at last, we get the full two-out-of-three property, and it is stronger than the partial results that we had for sheaves of finite presentation, in that we do not even need to assume that the sheaves are of finite type:
397#279unstable-279.xmlLemma#274
Let 0\to \mathscr {H}\to \mathscr {G}\to \mathscr {F}\to 0 be a short exact sequence of sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. If any two of \mathscr {H}, \mathscr {G}, and \mathscr {F} are coherent, then so too is the third.
398#280unstable-280.xmlProof#279
This is part of [Stacks:01BY].

In fact, we have an even better result than mere two-out-of-three:
399#281unstable-281.xmlCoherent sheaves form an abelian categoryLemma#274
The category of coherent sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules on a ringed space (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is an abelian category. Furthermore, its inclusion into the category of sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules is an exact functor.
400#282unstable-282.xmlProof#281
This is the rest of [Stacks:01BY].

fr:title.text: Coherence of the structure sheaf, and pullbacks and pushforwards

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coherence of the structure sheaf, and pullbacks and pushforwards

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Even though coherent sheaves give an abelian category when the other finiteness conditions did not, we have paid a price somewhere else: in general, it is not true that the pullback of a coherent sheaf is coherent. Even worse, there is no reason a priori for \mathscr {O}_X itself to be coherent, and so we cannot even ensure that (locally) free sheaves of finite rank are coherent — these should be a prototypical example of whatever sort of finiteness conditions we want, so the fact that the category of locally free sheaves is not necessarily a subcategory of the category of coherent sheaves is not a desirable outcome. But it turns out that the latter problem is somehow the only problem, in the sense of the following results:
403#284unstable-284.xmlLemma#283
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a ringed space, and \mathscr {F} a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules. If \mathscr {O}_X is coherent, then \mathscr {F} is coherent if and only if \mathscr {F} is of finite presentation.
404#285unstable-285.xmlProof#284 This is [Stacks:01BZ].
405#286unstable-286.xmlCorollary#283
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) and (Y,\mathscr {O}_Y) be ringed spaces, and f\colon (X,\mathscr {O}_X)\to (Y,\mathscr {O}_Y) a morphism. If \mathscr {O}_X is coherent, then the pullback functor f^* that sends sheaves of \mathscr {O}_Y-modules to sheaves of \mathscr {O}_X-modules respects coherence: the pullback of any coherent sheaf is again coherent.
406#287unstable-287.xmlProof#286
Any coherent \mathscr {O}_Y-module is in particular of finite presentation, and pullback always preserves being of finite presentation; since \mathscr {O}_X is coherent, being of finite presentation implies coherence, and so the pullback is coherent.

The fact that \mathscr {O}_X itself can be non-coherent is "not surprising", since an arbitrary ringed space with no further hypotheses could conceivably have "too many functions". There are two particularly important results concerning ringed spaces whose structure sheaf is coherent: one in algebraic geometry, and one in holomorphic geometry; the latter is one of the fundamental results in complex geometry.
407#288unstable-288.xmlNoetherian coherenceTheorem#283
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a locally Noetherian scheme. Then \mathscr {O}_X is a coherent \mathscr {O}_X-module.
408#289unstable-289.xmlProof#288
This is [Stacks:01XZ].
409#290unstable-290.xmlOka coherenceTheorem#283
Let (X,\mathscr {O}_X) be a complex manifold. Then \mathscr {O}_X is a coherent \mathscr {O}_X-module.
410#291unstable-291.xmlProof#290
TO-DO: give a good reference
412#292unstable-292.xmlRemark#290
One reason that this result is so deep is that it is somehow stronger than the corresponding result in algebraic geometry, since \mathscr {O}_X(X) is not a Noetherian ring in general for complex manifolds (e.g. for X a Stein manifold) and yet \mathscr {O}_X is still coherent.

Alongside Oka's coherence theorem, the other fundamental result for holomorphic geometry concerns pushforwards. Combining Oka's coherence theorem (or by assuming a locally Noetherian hypothesis, in the algebraic case) with TO-DO: the lemma about \mathscr {O}_X coherent implies pullback preserves coherence, we obtain functoriality of coherent sheaves for complex manifolds, in that \begin {aligned} \mathsf {RingSp} &\longrightarrow \mathsf {Cat} \\(X,\mathscr {O}_X) &\longmapsto \mathsf {Coh}(X) \\{}[f\colon (X,\mathscr {O}_X)\to (Y,\mathscr {O}_Y)] &\longmapsto [f^*\colon \mathsf {Coh}(Y)\to \mathsf {Coh}(X)] \end {aligned} defines a (pseudo-)functor from the category of ringed spaces to the category of (dg-)categories. More simply, for any morphism f\colon (X,\mathscr {O}_X)\to (Y,\mathscr {O}_Y) we obtain a pullback functor f^*\colon \mathsf {Coh}(Y)\to \mathsf {Coh}(X). It is then natural to ask if a similar stories holds true for a pushforward functor.

In general, for an arbitrary morphism f\colon (X,\mathscr {O}_X)\to (Y,\mathscr {O}_Y), it is not the case that the pushforward f_*\mathscr {F} of a coherent sheaf \mathscr {F} of \mathscr {O}_X-modules will again be coherent (as a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_Y-modules). However, this is true if we take f to be proper (by a result of Grauert–Remmert TO-DO: cite GR84, Theorem 10.4.6 in the holomorphic case, and Grothendieck TO-DO: cite EGA III, 3.2.1 in the algebraic case). Here we state only the holomorphic version; the algebraic version is [Stacks:02O3].

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Different finiteness conditions show up in different ways depending on the flavour of geometry being studied.

fr:li.fr:p: Algebraic geometry. For locally Noetherian schemes (X,\mathscr {O}_X), the structure sheaf \mathscr {O}_X is itself coherent ([Stacks:01XZ]). This implies, amongst other things, that a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules is then coherent if and only if it is finitely presented (also [Stacks:01XZ]). Since being locally Noetherian is not an overly restrictive hypothesis in general, some algebraic geometry references even define coherence as being finitely presented (or, equivalently, "quasi-coherent of finite type") — most notably TO-DO: Hartshorne.

Holomorphic geometry. For complex manifolds, the Noetherian condition is generally far too restrictive: any Stein manifold gives an example of a non-Noetherian (X,\mathscr {O}_X). What is arguably surprising, however, is that despite this the structure sheaf \mathscr {O}_X of any complex manifold is still coherent. This is a deep non-trivial theorem of Oka, and one of the fundamental results in complex geometry.

Differential geometry. For smooth manifolds, their structure sheaves are generally neither Noetherian nor coherent. In both cases, non-zero smooth functions with identically zero Taylor series on a neighbourhood are the problem. However, differential geometry can appeal to something that neither algebraic nor analytic geometry can: partitions of unity, with bump functions.

fr:title.text: Partitions of unity and the Nullstellensatz

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Partitions of unity and the Nullstellensatz

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Although the existence of partitions of unity in the smooth case is not expressed as a property of (X,\mathscr {O}_X), it still plays an analogous role to the coherence of \mathscr {O}_X, in that it gives rise to acyclicity theorems of resolutions. It is possible to think of the Nullstellensatz — a form of which holds in both the algebraic (over an algebraically closed field) and holomorphic cases — as a type of partition of unity statement: one version of it says that, for any set of functions f_1,\ldots ,f_n\in \mathscr {O}_X(X) that do not have a common zero, we can find g_1,\ldots ,g_n\in \mathscr {O}_X(X) such that \sum _i f_ig_i=1 (where X is affine in the algebraic case, and Stein in the holomorphic case). Indeed, this can even be proven by using coherence of the structure sheaf: it follows from Cartan's Theorem B. However, this analogy is not entirely precise, since partitions of unity involve extension by zero ("bump functions"), which is not possible in the algebraic or holomorphic cases; the fact that smooth partitions of unity are stronger (in this sense) is what implies that the structure sheaf of a smooth manifold is soft, and thus acyclic.

For a sheaf \mathscr {F} of \mathscr {O}_X-modules on a ringed space (X,\mathscr {O}_X), we have three classical finiteness conditions:
Finite type: locally covered by some finite free sheaf \mathscr {O}_U^{\oplus r}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}|_U (i.e. \mathscr {F} is locally finitely generated by sections)
Finite presentation: ... and all the extra fluff is locally the image of some finite free sheaf \mathscr {O}_V^{\oplus s}\to \mathscr {O}_V^{\oplus r}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}|_V (i.e. \mathscr {F} is locally the cokernel of a finite free morphism)
Coherent: ... and this whole story is also true of any subsheaf of finite type \left [ \mathscr {F}'\hookrightarrow \mathscr {F} \quad \text {and}\quad \mathscr {O}_U^{\oplus r'}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}'_U \right ] \implies \left [ \mathscr {O}_V^{\oplus s'}\to \mathscr {O}_V^{\oplus r'}\twoheadrightarrow \mathscr {F}'|_V \right ] (i.e. \mathscr {F} is locally the cokernel of a finite free morphism, as are all its subsheaves of finite type)
(where V\subseteq U\subseteq X).
Coherence allows us to turn exactness on stalks to exactness on neighbourhoods.

fr:li.fr:p: In general, [finite type \Longleftarrow finite presentation \Longleftarrow coherent].
For any subsheaf of a coherent sheaf, these three conditions become equivalent.
[Stacks:01BZ]: If \mathscr {O}_X itself is coherent, then [finite presentation \iff coherent].
In particular, if \mathscr {O}_X is coherent, then any locally free sheaf of finite rank (i.e. any "vector bundle") is also coherent.

[Stacks:01XZ]: If (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a locally Noetherian scheme, then these three conditions are almost equivalent: for any sheaf, [finite type* \iff finite presentation \iff coherent], where "finite type*" means quasi-coherent of finite type (but we don't want to talk about quasi-coherence right now).
In particular, if (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a locally Noetherian scheme, then \mathscr {O}_X is coherent, and the proof of this is trivial: it's of finite presentation (indeed, it's even of finite type).

The fact that \mathscr {O}_X is coherent when (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a complex manifold is a deep theorem of Oka whose proof is not at all trivial. Indeed, (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is not Noetherian in the case where X is in particular a Stein manifold, so we cannot simply copy the algebraic proof and say that it follows from \mathscr {O}_X being of finite type.

When (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is a smooth manifold, then (X,\mathscr {O}_X) is not Noetherian and also \mathscr {O}_X is not coherent. This would cause a lot of issues, were it not for the fact that partitions of unity allow differential geometers to build acyclic resolutions in the form of flasque sheaves.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Looking up the definition of what it means for a sheaf of \mathscr {O}_X-modules to be coherent will give different results depending on the reference, both in terms of when it was written and what its focus is. For example, you might hear people complain that "the definition in EGA (TO-DO: citation) is not functorial (it's not preserved by pullbacks)", or that "the definition in Hartshorne (TO-DO: citation) makes Oka coherence sound trivial". Lots of confusion stems from the fact that, when dealing with (locally) Noetherian schemes, or ringed spaces with coherent structure sheaf (such as complex manifolds), the differences between various finiteness conditions collapse somewhat, making it hard to tell that they were actually distinct in the first place. Not only this, but references dealing with algebraic geometry (in the sense that they talk about schemes) are likely to discuss quasi-coherent sheaves, which are not well-behaved objects for arbitrary locally ringed spaces, and definitely not well-behaved in the specific case of complex manifolds.

Part of the reason for this confusing proliferation of competing definitions is the historical journey coherent sheaves have taken: they started in complex geometry, worked their way into algebraic geometry, and then through into scheme theory.

Furthermore, for any choice of open cover \mathcal {U} of the manifold, we can construct the holomorphic twisting cochain to be with respect to a refinement of \mathcal {U}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a corollary (TO-DO: explain how!) to [Wei2016, Proposition 3.20], though the terminology there is different: their "twisted perfect complexes" are (roughly) exactly twisting cochains.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
[Wei2016] deals with two other important results:
"Twisted coherent complexes", which deal with bounded-above (instead of bounded) complexes; this is spelled out in detail in the algebraic case, but it should be possible to translate it to the general case by working with pseudo-coherence instead (as mentioned in Remark 5.2 loc. cit.)
The fully general "sheafification functor" concerns (not necessarily perfect) complexes of sheaves and "twisted complexes", which are like twisting cochains but the (not-necessarily-bounded) complexes consist of arbitrary sheaves, not just locally free ones. It is conjectured (in Section 5.3 loc. cit.) that there is still a Quillen equivalence at this full level of generality.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathscr {F} be a coherent sheaf on a holomorphic manifold. Then \mathscr {F} admits a resolution by a holomorphic twisting cochain. Furthermore, for any choice of open cover \mathcal {U} of the manifold, we can construct the holomorphic twisting cochain to be with respect to a refinement of \mathcal {U}.

Let \mathscr {F}^\bullet be a perfect complex on a holomorphic manifold. Then \mathscr {F}^\bullet admits a resolution by a holomorphic twisting cochain. Furthermore, for any choice of open cover \mathcal {U} of the manifold, we can construct the holomorphic twisting cochain to be with respect to a refinement of \mathcal {U}.
Let \mathscr {F}^\bullet be a perfect complex (such that each \mathscr {F}^i is quasi-coherent) on a locally ringed space. Then \mathscr {F}^\bullet admits a resolution by a twisting cochain.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a corollary (TO-DO: explain how!) to [Wei2016, Proposition 3.20], though the terminology there is different: their "twisted perfect complexes" are (roughly) exactly twisting cochains.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
[Wei2016] deals with two other important results:
"Twisted coherent complexes", which deal with bounded-above (instead of bounded) complexes; this is spelled out in detail in the algebraic case, but it should be possible to translate it to the general case by working with pseudo-coherence instead (as mentioned in Remark 5.2 loc. cit.)
The fully general "sheafification functor" concerns (not necessarily perfect) complexes of sheaves and "twisted complexes", which are like twisting cochains but the (not-necessarily-bounded) complexes consist of arbitrary sheaves, not just locally free ones. It is conjectured (in Section 5.3 loc. cit.) that there is still a Quillen equivalence at this full level of generality.
